channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: UN Pension Review Raises Concerns Among Staff and Retirees
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly’s latest pension fund resolution — adopted at the end of December 2025 — has triggered concerns among current and former staff members of the organization that their retirement security may be at risk. The resolution invites the UN Pension Board to carry out a full review of the pension system, ... Read more

item.title: As AI rises and aid declines, can Davos shape a new compact for development?
item.description: Opinion: At Davos, governments, donors, and institutions could agree that a share of AI-driven efficiency gains in high-income settings be reinvested in frontline services and local capability in lower-income countries.

item.title: Karatoya
item.description: Once a lifeline of northern Bengal, Bangladesh’s Karatoya River now drifts through Bogura as a fragmented, polluted channel, where climate change and human neglect quietly reshape livelihoods, memory, and everyday life. Flowing through the heart of Bogura, the Karatoya River bears the weight of a long, visible decline. Once one of northern Bengal’s major […]

item.title: Money Matters: What’s in the $50 billion US aid budget?
item.description: Plus, inside the United States’ new approach to funding the U.N., Germany’s new aid plan, and a look at how the Novo Nordisk Foundation funds aid.

item.title: Which countries received the most ODA in 2024?
item.description: $163.3 billion in bilateral official development assistance was provided in 2024. Which countries received the most money? Devex crunched the numbers to find out.

item.title: Celebrated soil scientist and food security activist Pedro Sánchez dies
item.description: The food security and agricultural science communities mourn the passing of a “giant in the field,” Pedro Sánchez, who transformed farming across Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

item.title: How MCC plans to award $287.3 million in contracts in 2026
item.description: The Millennium Challenge Corporation had almost the same budget for anticipated awards as in the last fiscal year, but for a much smaller number of contracts.

item.title: Devex Newswire: What to make of development in 2026
item.description: Devex President and Editor-in-Chief Raj Kumar offers up his predictions for the year ahead.

item.title: The UN’s Withering Vine: A US Retreat from Global Governance
item.description: The Trump administration’s recent announcement of its withdrawal from 66 international organisations has been met with a mixture of alarm and applause. While the headline number suggests a dramatic retreat from the world stage, a closer look reveals a more nuanced, and perhaps more insidious, strategy. The move is less a wholesale abandonment of […]

item.title: One Carries a Broom, the Other a Schoolbag
item.description: While other children her age prepared for school, eight-year-old Tania once began her workday. Each morning, she picked up a jharu—the household broom—and cleaned floors inside a private home. At the same time, another child of her age in that household lifted a schoolbag and left for class. One carried a broom. The other carried […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: Congress speaks up about US foreign aid. Will it matter?
item.description: While the $50 billion funding bill reinstates funding for programs the administration had previously slashed, it remains uncertain whether the Trump administration will respect Congress’ authority to control government spending. Plus, preparing for development discussions in Davos.

item.title: Yemen: Children are dying and it’s going to get worse, warns aid veteran
item.description: In Yemen, renewed political instability and economic woes linked to the war threaten to complicate the already difficult task of helping vulnerable people suffering from deepening hunger, illness and displacement, the UN’s top aid official there said on Monday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Food insecurity in Lebanon, Libya migrants freed, UNHCR tackles multiple emergencies – despite cuts
item.description: Since 2026, nearly 17 percent of Lebanon’s population has been living in a state of major food insecurity – a situation that is likely to worsen in the coming year.

item.title: ‘Alarming’ increase in use of death penalty last year, despite global trend towards abolition
item.description: Despite a downward trend in the use of the death penalty globally, 2025 saw an ‘alarming’ increase in the number of executions in a small number of retentionist countries, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) warned on Monday.

item.title: Sudan: Atrocities ‘repeated town by town’, ICC prosecutor tells UN Security Council
item.description: Atrocities in Sudan’s Darfur region are spreading from town to town in an organized campaign of violence that includes mass executions, rape and ethnic targeting, amounting to war crimes and crimes against humanity, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court told the UN Security Council on Monday.

item.title: Davos tests the limits in a world of power, profit, and inequality
item.description: As world leaders and billionaires descend on Davos, rising inequality and collapsing multilateralism raise questions about development’s place at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Devex Pro Insider: Power on display in Davos, but does dialogue wield any of it?
item.description: What to expect at this week's World Economic Forum in Davos. Plus, one health leader announces her bid for U.S. Congress, while another criticizes the state of Nigeria’s health system.

item.title: Can digital public infrastructure reshape donor-reliant health systems?
item.description: For years, digital health in Africa followed donor funding — often fragmented, short-term, and hard to sustain. Now, as aid contracts, countries are betting on digital public infrastructure to do things differently.

item.title: How Extreme Weather is Testing Tanzania’s $2 Billion Electric Railway Dream
item.description: Around the world, railways are considered as pillars of climate action. Electric trains produce fewer emissions than road or air transport. Yet the experience of Tanzania’s Standard Gauge Railway highlights a growing paradox: infrastructure designed to be climate-friendly is itself increasingly exposed to climate shocks.

item.title: Economic Dogma Blocks Pragmatic Policies
item.description: After condemning pragmatic responses to the 1997-98 Asian financial crises, the West pursued similar policies in response to the 2008 global financial crisis without acknowledging its own mistakes. Politicised exchange rates After US Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker sharply raised interest rates from late 1979 to curb inflation, the dollar’s value strengthened despite deepening stagnation. […]

item.title: Children and Armed Conflict Must be at the Forefront of the Global Agenda
item.description: Thirty years ago, the groundbreaking report by Graça Machel, renowned and widely respected global advocate for women’s and children’s rights, to the United Nations General Assembly laid bare the devastating impact of armed conflict on children and shook the conscience of the world. It led to the historic decision of the General Assembly to create […]
